user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
```c
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext:
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED ((osal_id_t){0})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I selected the above statements as candidates for investigation with respect to MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 because they are executed assignments/operations whose removal could — in some configurations or usages — be redundant or have no observable effect; they therefore merit review to ensure none are truly dead code. Other fragments in the function do not need investigation for dead-code concerns: the function signature and local variable declarations are required for correct compilation and semantics; the do/while(!got_next) loop structure and the use of the got_next flag are the loop control mechanisms (removing them would clearly change behavior rather than be dead); the increment of obj_idx together with the index check and the macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET are the mechanism to step through the table and fetch records (their purpose is evident and removal would alter behavior); and the return of the boolean result is the observable outcome of the function. In short, only the specific executed assignments/operations listed above deserve further inspection to determine whether, in the broader project context, any of them are actually dead (i.e., could be removed without changing program behavior).
